subject: Programming
title: Quicksort and Practical Speed
description: A micro-lesson that makes Quicksort and Practical Speed usable.

hook.text: Quicksort was invented in 1960 and is still the default in most programming libraries.

buildup.text: It picks a pivot element, partitions the list around it, then recursively sorts both sides.

discovery.text: On average, quicksort runs in O(n log n) and uses less memory than merge sort.

twist.text: In the worst case, quicksort degrades to O(nÂ²). Bad pivot choices can ruin performance.

climax.text: Randomizing the pivot nearly eliminates worst cases. Quicksort wins in practice, not theory.

punchline.text: Theory says it can fail. Practice says it rarely does.

quiz.question: What is quicksort's worst-case time complexity?
